title: Wayfarer's Walk Route

images.title: Colin Smith / Wayfarer's Walk, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Long distance track, seen here just west of Freemantle Farm. The flint of the underlying Downs is easily visible on the track surface. The path runs between Emsworth and Inkpen Beacon.

images.title: Pam Brophy / Wayfarer's Walk, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A view of the slopes of the hill used for pasture and grazing. Taken near Pilot Hill and Ashmansworth

images.title: Peter Facey / Prite Lane, Wayfarer's Walk, Tichborne, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Prite Lane, Tichborne.

images.title: Peter Facey / Totford Farm seen from Wayfarer's Walk, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Totford Farm seen from Wayfarer's Walk near Northington. The B3046 is in the hedge beyond.

images.title: Brian Green / Wayfarer's Walk, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Footpath along the edge of Emsworth Harbour

images.title: Peter Facey / Grounds of Breach House seen from Wayfarer's Walk, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Grounds of Breach House seen from Wayfarer's Walk. With Breach Farm buildings behind.

images.title: Peter Facey / Looking across water meadows to Cheriton from Wayfarer's Walk, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking across water meadows to Cheriton

images.title: Andrew Johnson / Dummer House from Wayfarer's Walk, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Dummer House from Wayfarer's Walk

description: Starting at the town of Emsworth on Chichester Harbour, follow this fabulous 70 mile walk through the heart of Hampshire and on into Berkshire. You will pass through the pretty Hampshire towns and villages of Cheriton, Droxford, Hambledon and New Arlesford while also experiencing the beautiful landscape and wildlife in this special county. The path is easy to follow as it is waymarked by metal and plastic disks attached to wooden and metal posts. Highlights on the route in include the National Trust owned Hinton Ampner stately home with its wonderful gardens and Watership Down - the delightful setting for Richard Adams' 1972 novel. The route passes the wonderful 5000 acre estate surrounding Highclere Castle in Hampshire. The house is famous as the location of period drama 'Downton Abbey' and includes the excellent viewpoint at Beacon Hill. There are also some lovely waterside stretches to enjoy at Cheriton along the River Itchen and along the River Arle at New Arlesford. The walk finishes at Walbury Hill, the highest point in Berkshire and the South East of England.
